pullRequest.body:
This PR adds the Mahler basis functions, which are the functions `x â†¦ x.choose k` on `â„¤_[p]`. This is preparation for Mahler's theorem (to be added in a subsequent PR), which shows that these functions are a Banach space basis for the space of continuous functions on `â„¤_[p]`.

Partially based on the ETH bachelor thesis of Giulio Caflisch.

 ---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]


-->
- [x] depends on: #18410

Hi! Do you have plan to formalize various distribution spaces over Qp in Colmez's 1998 paper *Theorie d'Iwasawa des representations de de Rham d'un corps local*?

> Hi! Do you have plan to formalize various distribution spaces over Qp in Colmez's 1998 paper _Theorie d'Iwasawa des representations de de Rham d'un corps local_?

For now, I am concentrating on continuous functions and their dual, measures (tempered distributions of order 0). I believe there is a group at BICMR working on the more general setting of functions and distributions of positive order; there was some [discussion of this on Zulip recently](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/channel/217875-Is-there-code-for-X.3F/topic/Zp.20is.20compact.3F). 

(Mahler's theorem has been formalised before, but has never made it into mathlib; so I am concentrating on getting this theorem in before building more on top of it.)

This PR/issue depends on:
* ~~leanprover-community/mathlib4#18410~~
By **[Dependent Issues](https://github.com/z0al/dependent-issues)** (ðŸ¤–). Happy coding!
<!-- By Dependent Issues (Action) - DO NOT REMOVE -->

@ScottCarnahan Thanks for the suggestion to try using `BinomialRing`! After some initial struggles this eventually worked out rather nicely. So the PR now proves that Z_p is a binomial ring and derives the results from that, as you suggested.
Thanks Michael! All comments now dealt with.
maintainer merge
ðŸš€ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by MichaelStollBayreuth.

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11620097663/job/32361151385)
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/11620097663/job/32361151113)

Thanks :tada:

bors merge
This looks great. Thanks for cleaning up my diamond!
This looks great. Thanks for cleaning up my diamond!
LGTM, modulo the suggested fixes to comments in the code.

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

The underlying function is `Ring.choose x k` (from `RingTheory.Binomial`). I'm not sure if you want to go through the trouble of producing a `BinomialRing` instance for `Z_[p]` and proving continuity with this alternative definition, though.  It would however make `mathler_natCast_eq` superfluous.

We wondered about using the `BinomialRing` machinery but didn't pursue it, since I wasn't sure how easy it would be to prove continuity from this definition. But if having a BinomialRing instance on Zp is something that would be useful in its own right then we can try that route instead. (I think there are no other examples of BinomialRings at present except N and Z, so having another one can't do any harm.)

So I tried, and it wasn't much fun. Obtaining a `BinomialRing` instance on Zp is not too bad, it's just a reorganisation of the code we already have for showing that `â€–mahler kâ€– = 1`. But if you define `mahler k` using `Ring.choose`, deriving continuity from this seems to be quite awkward; I got as far as proving a goal which printed as `(descPochhammer â„¤ k).smeval x = (descPochhammer â„¤ k).smeval x`, for `x : â„¤_[p]`, but unfortunately the LHS and RHS seem to be using two different definitions of `smul` which Mathlib is unable to show are the same.

```suggestion
  -- find `n : â„•` such that `â€–f x - f nâ€– â‰¤ â€–k!â€–`
```
At least, this is what is actually done here...
I assume this comment should be modified in the same way.
You actually use that the binomial coefficient is a natural number.

```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
lemma continuous_multichoose (k : â„•) : Continuous (fun x : â„¤_[p] â†¦ Ring.multichoose x k) := by
  simp only [Ring.multichoose, BinomialRing.multichoose, continuous_induced_rng]
  fun_prop
```

```suggestion
@[fun_prop]
lemma continuous_choose (k : â„•) : Continuous (fun x : â„¤_[p] â†¦ Ring.choose x k) := by
  simp only [Ring.choose]
  fun_prop
```

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(NumberTheory/Padics): Mahler basis functions
